comments:
During the build process, it appears Eclipse deletes old files and then 
rebuilds them.  When Eclipse does a full build, sometimes it appears to attempt 
to delete files that are already deleted.  This causes the build to fail 
complaining that it can not delete the file that has already been deleted.  
Could the code be changed to detect if the reason that the delete failed is 
because the file doesn't exist and then to carry on with the build, without 
throwing an error?

The log of the error is below.

Deletion failures are usually caused by some process keeping an open file
descriptor on a file.  In this case it looks like someone is holding an open
descriptor on "OfferConf.dtd".  Was this file open in an editor? Is there some
other plugin that might have been operating on that file?  Do you have just the
Eclipse SDK plugins installed or additional plugins? If you have other plugins,
do you still get the deletion failure when they are not installed?

The setup is Eclipse installed as standard (No extra plugins).  The files are 
residing on a Solaris machine with Solaris Lanman being using to export the 
file system to the windows platform.  The file wasn't open at the time.  I also 
went as far as blowing away the whole directory structure from resources/ in an 
effort to get Eclipse to build but to no avail.
Not reproducible.  Someone must have been holding an open file descriptor on "OfferConf.dtd". Without a reproducible case we won't be able to investigate this further.
